ADVANCED Arbitrary Image Scaler ADVANCED Arbitrary Image Scaler CV5x can export the image digital signal processor IDSP mixer to enable user applications to perform up- down-scaling Using the scaler a user-specified input buffer can be cropped and scaled up or down to the chosen output size Because the arbitrary image scaler is multiplexed with the source buffer when it is enabled the seventh source buffer must be disabled for all channels and cannot be used as a pyramid input buffer Figure 1-1 Arbitrary Image Scaler Resolution and Scalability The maximum input buffer size can be up to 1 4 3 3 6 x14336 The maximum output buffer size can be up to 1 4 3 3 6 x8192 The image scaler supports up to 8 x upscaling and 1 downscaling Input Data Format Three types of YUV formats are supported for the input output I/O buffer YUV400 YUV420 YUV422 Once designated the format of the I/O buffer must be kept the same Buffer Address Alignment The buffer pitch of the input buffer should be aligned to 6 4 on CV5x and aligned to 1 2 8 on CV72 The x-offset and width of cropping window must be aligned to 4 the y-offset and height must be aligned to two When the buffer width is aligned to 4 but not aligned to 6 4 or 1 2 8 such as 7 2 0 it must be padded to be aligned to 6 4 or 1 2 8 before image scaling is performed The buffer pitch of the output buffer must be aligned to 6 4 on CV5x and aligned to 1 2 8 on CV72 and the buffer width must be aligned to 4 When the buffer width is aligned to 4 but is not aligned to 6 4 or 1 2 8 such as 3 6 0 it must be padded to be aligned to 6 4 or 1 2 8 before image scaling is performed

ADVANCED Configure with Lua Script ADVANCED Configure with Lua Script For a specific product design user applications must configure the various resource and layout settings including video input VIN multi-VIN canvas stream and video output VOUT In order to make the parameters easier to parse the Lua script file is introduced as the configuration file for these resource and layout settings The Lua script improves the organization of parameters and multi-VIN design options This Lua script format is an excellent reference for users to configure their own implementation and file formats to organize these options Generally a Lua script is comprised of five main sections Video source VSRC configuration Each sensor either an RGB sensor such as or a YUV input device such as is enumerated as a instance In the Lua script all sensor-related configurations are included in this section Channel configuration A channel is an independent unit for the image digital signal processor IDSP to process image data generated by sensor Each channel possesses its own 3 A parameters including a different IDSP pipeline It also has a set of source buffers main second third and its own Pyramid buffers In the Lua script all channel-related configurations are included in this section Canvas configuration The canvas maintains the channels source buffers It can be either outputed through video output VOUT or encoded to streams User applications can combine the field of view FoV of each channel s source buffer together into one canvas so that the stream encoded from this canvas can cover several FoVs from different VIN channels Alternatively each source buffer can have its own canvas Stream configuration Canvases can be encoded as streams with various stream numbers and configurations In the Lua script all stream-related configurations are included in this section Resource All configurations mentioned above will be collected into this section Table 2 1 VSRC Common Configuration Item Description vsrc_id Specify the sensor input ID Ambarella suggests keeping the same value as a sensor index which is automatically generated during sensor driver probing and corresponds to a real sensor vsrc_status Specify if the sensor is active or broken not connected mode Specify the sensor resolutions hdr_mode Specify the HDR mode or linear mode such or wide dynamic range fps Specify the sensor framerate vsrc_ctx_switch Enable vsrc_ctx by switching the VIN driver It is required for some sensors such as AR0230 and AR0237 which can support multiple register groups of the shutter and active gain contol AGC vsrc_ctx but must switch among them manually via the VIN driver bits Specify the sensor RGB bits 0 for AUTO 8 1 6 for specified bits mirror Specify the sensor mirror pattern 0 none 1 flip 2 mirror 3 mirror and flip 2 5 5 AUTO bayer Specify the sensor Bayer pattern 0 RG 1 BG 2 GR 3 GB 2 5 5 AUTO scale_type Specify the VIN scale type 0 no scale 1 1 for both width and height 2 1 for width and 1 for height 3 1 only for width 4 1 only for width the default is 0 roi_enable Flag to enable ROI VIN roi_list Specifies the crop window of each ROI VIN Example Table 2 2 Custom Virtual VIN Mode Configuration Item Description width VSRC output window width height VSRC output window height hdr_mode Specify HDR mode for the virtual sensor default_fps Specify the default frame rate of the virtual sensor max_fps Specify the maximum frame rate of the virtual sensor bits Specify the virtual sensor RGB bits hdr_offset_long Line offset of the longest exposure frame hdr_offset_short1 Line offset of the medium exposure frame hdr_offset_short2 Line offset of the above-medium exposure frame hdr_offset_short3 Line offset of the shortest exposure frame sensor_id Specify the sensor_id of the virtual sensor agc_db_step Specify the agc_db_step of the virtual sensor dual_gain_mode Flag to indicate if the current VIN supports dual-gain mode video_type Specify the virtual sensor video type Example for Virtual VIN Mode Lua Configuration Table 3 1 Channel Configuration Item Description id Specify the channel ID Ambarella recommends that users keep the same value as the channel index starting from zero vsrc Specify the channel VSRC The content must be declared before the channel definition in the Lua script idsp_fps Specify the resample IDSP output framerate idsp_fps_locked_enable Enable locking IDSP output framerate If it is disabled idsp_fps is updated proportionally when the VIN framerate is changed at runtime While it is enabled idsp_fps will remain constant regardless of how the VIN framerate is changed vsrc_ctx Specify the sensor register context of the VSRC for the channel It only functions for some sensors such as AR0230 which support multiple register groups for shutter and AGC use_vsrc_ctx_pattern Specify if the IDSP splits the VIN frame into the current channel according to its vsrc_ctx_pattern Specify the data pattern which is embedded in the first line of sensor data vsrc_ctx_pattern_mask Specify valid bits in sensor_ctrl Tells the sensor driver which channel is allowed to configure the shutter and AGC It is only used for special cases img_stats_src_chan Tells the 3 A process which channel s statistics are used to perform 3 A control for the channel It is used for multi-channel stitching and IDSP virtual channel cases app_img_profile Specify 3 A image profile mode 0 IPC 1 BWC 2 ITS 3 DVR 4 DMS 5 ADAS 6 OMC 7 eMIRROR packing_mode_enable Enable VIN packing mode only when VIN RAW compression is disabled to save dynamic random-access memory DRAM bandwidth raw_capture Enable capture of RAW data or RAW slice data from the RGB sensor Users can get more information from the help message of the unit test application test_yucap ext_mem Enable RAW external memory raw_manual_feed Enable RAW manual feed raw_feed_frame_num Specify the RAW feed buffer number raw_cached_items Specify the RAW cache buffer number The system will not discard RAW data immediately but place it in the cache buffer if raw_cached_items 0 This provides users with a greater time margin to query it raw_slice_num Specify the captured number of RAW slice data If raw_slice_num 1 it will be enabled and raw_slice_num should be in range 1 8 raw_slice_cached_items Specify the RAW slice cache buffer number The system will not discard RAW slice data immediately but place it in the cache buffer if raw_slice_num 1 This provides users with a greater time margin to query it y12_enable Enable C2Y Y12 output y12_cached_items Specify Y12 cached items for user to query with blocking call mctf_cmpr Enable motion-compensated temporal filtering MCTF compression expo_num Specify the DOLHDR exposure frames number vcap_mode_flags Specify vcap_mode for each channel The following are the vcap modes for different cases 0 x00 Advanced ISO mode This is the mode for lowest latency from VIN to VOUT 0 x05 Line-interleaved HDR mode This is the mode for 3 X HDR and multi-pass scale 0 x08 Image Pipeline Only mode This is the mode for EIS source channel 0 x09 AI ISP mode This is the mode for AI ISP 0 x0B Custom AI ISP mode This is the mode for Custom AI ISP 0 x7F Mode none This is the mode to skip ISP processing for current channel 0 x80 Automatic mode This flag enables vcap_mode_flags to follow encode_mode vsrc_region_num Specify the total region number of the source sensor Multiple vsrc_region must be stored in line-interleaved format in sensor data vsrc_region_map Specify region index map from which the current channel captures the sensor data enable_group Enable channel grouping group_idx Specify channel group index group_order_idx Specify channel order idx inside the group with the group index group_sync Enable group synchronization among channels of same group Only valid when and are set reuse_src_chan_iso_cfg Reuse ISO cfg from its source channel for current channel extra_iso_cfg Specify the extra ISO cfg num for current channel lens_warp Enable the lens distortion correction LDC function max_padding_width Specify the padding width at C2Y stage RAW processing stage for LDC on this channel It must function with the option max_warp_input_width Specify the maximum input width for dewarp max_warp_output_width Specify the maximum output width for dewarp max_vwarp_wait_lines Specify the waiting lines for vwarp max_vwarp_blk_height Specify maximum vwarp block height for LDC use case rotate_cw Enable 9 0 degree clockwise rotation hflip Enable horizontal flipping vflip Enable vertical flipping extra_downscale Enable the large down-scale When the downscale ratio is larger than or equal than 6 X it should be set to 1 eis_delay_count Specify electronic image stabilization EIS delay frame number before IDSP pipeline for each channel raw_src_chan Specify RAW source channel for EIS channel For EIS it is implemented with dual channels c2y_burst_tile Enable C2Y burst tile mode By default it is 1 max_main_input_width Specify the maximum main buffer input width It can help the DSP to allocate the proper resources from various cases It must be configured when the user application requires a small main buffer input size such as 7 2 0 x480 with a large VIN size such as 3 8 4 0 x2160 If it is set the main buffer input width cannot exceed it through the run-time update during Preview Encoding slice_cfg_enable Enable slice-related configurations slice_num Specify the slice number at the Y2Y stage YUV domain processing stage Only valid when is enabled slice_width Specify single-slice width at the Y2Y stage YUV domain processing stage Only valid when is enabled warp_padding_width Specify the padding width for YUV data at the Y2Y stage YUV domain processing stage when IDSP stitching is used Only valid when is enabled chan_input_src Specify the channel input source 0 RAW data 1 CE data 2 Low-resolution data This parameter should be 0 for most cases Only for EIS use cases it can be 1 or 2 to improve IDSP performance idsp_core_cfg_enable Enable IDSP dual-core configurations for this channel By default it is 0 idsp_core_mode Specify the IDSP core modes for this channel Only valid when is enabled 0 single-core 0 1 single-core 1 2 dual-cores pre_dec_enable Enable decoding function before channel processing Only enable it for decoding channel pre_dec_type Specify the decoder type for the decoding Only valid when pre_dec_enable is 1 pass_num Specify the pass number for which IDSP generates source buffers premain main second third fourth fifth sixth Specify the buffer output of each channel vin_roi_idx Specify the index of ROI VIN Only valid when in vsrc configuration is enabled ver_slice_num Specify the IDSP vertical slice number Default is 1 raw_padding_height Specify the padding height of the raw image Default is 0 Example Table 3 2 Buffer Configuration Item Description max_output width height Specify the maximum output width height of each source buffer input offset_x offset_y width height Specify the input window of each source buffer The main buffer input window is cropped from sensor VSRC resolution and other source buffer input windows are cropped from the main buffer output window output offset_x offset_y width height Specify the output window of each source buffer in the canvas The output offset is in the canvas coordinate Table 3 3 Pyramid Configuration Item Description input_buf_id Specify the input source buffer ID in this channel scale_type Specify the pyramid layer scale ratio 0 1 2 1 1 2 Arbitrary size When scale_type is 2 the downscaling ratio between layer_0 and layer_1 can be arbitrary The size of layer_1 is specified through rescale_size width height While for the remaining layers the downscaling ratio are fixed to 1 ext_mem Enable the external memory for pyramid buffers It is 0 when the pyramid is from DSP s internal buffer When it is 1 the pyramid buffer pool is allocated by the IAV driver and pyramid buffer is automatically generated by DSP into the external pyramid buffer pool frame_rate Specify the pyramid frame rate it must be less than idsp_fps This feature is not yet supported manual_feed Enable manual-feed mode 0 Pyramid auto-generation mode 1 Pyramid manual-feed mode item_num Specify the number of pyramid buffers in pyramid manual-feed mode It must be within the range of 4 1 2 When set to 0 it uses 6 as a default rescale_size width height Specify the size of layer_1 when scale_type is 2 max_rescale_size width height Specify the max size of layer_1 layer_map Specify which layers are not enabled to reduce DRAM bandwidth To enable all seven layers set this to 0 x7F max_layer_map Specify maximum bitmaps for pyramid layers one bit for one layer This can only be changed before entering into preview The must be within crop_win offset_x offset_y width height Specify the output window of each pyramid layer buffer The default value 0 0 0 0 refers to the pyramid layer s active window without cropping rather than the window with the size 0 x0 The cropping window of current layer will not affect latter layers Example Table 4 1 Canvas Configuration Item Description type Specify the canvas type It can be either or There is no type for canvas If the application must turn off the canvas it has to reconfigure the system and remove the canvas definition If the canvas type is previewed it can be in either YUV422 or YUV420 format with UV-interleaved data If the canvas type is encoded it must be in YUV420 format with UV-interleaved data size width height Specify the canvas resolution source Specify source buffers of channels to canvas The DSP follows the source buffer declare order in order to place a channel source buffer data in this field The latter source buffer is placed in with a higher Z order and may cover the source buffer with a lower Z order The channels whose source buffer are placed into the same canvas must have the same extra_dram_buf Specify extra DRAM frames for the canvas vout_id Specify VOUT when canvas type is If the value is set to 1 VOUT1 such as high-definition multimedia interface HDMIÂ® or composite video with blanking and sync CVBS will be used to show preview canvas If the value is set to 0 VOUT0 such as LDC or DSI will be used to show the preview canvas vout_YUV422 Specify YUV format when the canvas type is If the value is set to 1 its YUV format is YUV422 Then VOUT captures the display data from it directly If the value is set to 0 its YUV format is YUV420 which is the same as other type canvases Then VOUT will convert it to YUV422 before showing vout_back_pressure_margin Specify the current VOUT input FIFO depth Valid range is 0 3 0 means using the default value 2 manual_feed Enable manual-feed mode 0 Canvas auto-generation mode 1 Canvas manual-feed mode feed_frame_num Specify the number of canvas buffers in manual-feed mode It must be within the range of 4 1 2 When set to 0 it uses 6 as a default cached_items Specify the canvas cache buffer number The system will not discard canvas data immediately but place it in the cache buffer if cached_items 0 This provides users with a greater time margin to query it enc_dummy_latency Specify the latency number of the encode dummy buffer frame_rate Specify the canvas frame rate it must be less than idsp_fps zero_fps Enable 0 fps canvas frame rate When set to 0 represents idsp_fps When set to 1 is real 0 fps set_min_unlocked_buf_num Enable set min_unlocked_buf_num config 1 Enable 0 Disable min_unlocked_buf_num Specify minimum number of Pyramid unlocked buffers When users want to set min_unlocked_buf_num accordingly they must enable manual_feed and set_min_unlocked_buf_num first disable_yuv_dram Enable DSP to allocate the canvas YUV buffer which is used to save memory when users have such requirements 0 Default Allocate buffer 1 Do not allocate buffer enable_frame_tag Enable canvas frame tag pattern feature frame_tag_value Specify canvas frame tag value This value is valid when enable_frame_tag flag is enabled frame_tag_mask Specify canvas frame tag mask This value is valid when enable_frame_tag flag is enabled ext_mem Enable the external memory for the canvas YUV data blend_stitch_type Specify the blend stitch type for this canvas when multiple-channel stitching is used 0 No stitch blending 1 Horizontal stitch blending 2 Vertical stitch blending blend_stitch_circular_margin Specify The overlap margin of the last channel and first channel Only valid when isn t 0 blend_warp_enable Enable H warp for blending overlap region Only valid when isn t 0 blur_enable Enable blur insertion into the canvas This is only for canvases whose type is max_blur_area_num Maximum possible blur areas to insert Valid range is 0 8 0 means using the default value 8 enc_extra_padding_enable Enable extra padding for streams encoding with offset 1 Enable 0 Disable low_delay_enable This is a flag to enable disable canvas low delay output with multiple vertical slices enabled Default is 0 Example Table 5 1 Stream Configuration Item Description id Specify the stream ID Ambarella recommends keeping the same value as the stream index starting from zero max_size Specify the maximum stream resolution max_M Specify the maximum group of pictures GOP M for the stream For B frames max_M 1 For MJPEG encoding max_M 0 fast_seek_enable Enable the Fast Seek frame two_ref_enable Enable two forward reference frames max_svct_layers_minus_1 Specify maximum scalable video coding SVC-T layers options 0 No SVC-T 1 Two-layer SVC-T max_num_minus_1_ltrs Specify the maximum long-term number minus 1 possible_enc_src_map Specify the encoding source canvas map for the encoding stream 0 default all canvases Users should specify when the stream will be encoded with advanced GOP Advanced GOP requires more memory resources to be allocated for the source canvases By default DSP allocates memory resources for all canvases Specifying the designated source canvases can save memory codec_enable Enable the stream codec 0 High-efficiency video coding HEVC H.264 MJPEG 1 HEVC MJPEG 2 H.264 MJPEG 3 MJPEG only efm_enable Specify if the current stream can run encode from memory EFM efm_buf_num Specify the number of frame buffers allocated for EFM These frame buffers are allocated by DSP and occupy extra memory efm_size Specify the EFM frame buffer size efm_skip_waiting Enable skip waiting for DSP s response when starting stopping EFM streams efm_extern_src_enable Enable sharing EFM buffers from other streams efm_ext_mem Enable external memory as the EFM stream input stream_mv_statis_enable Enable stream motion vector statistics stream_pic_statis_enable Enable stream frame encoding information statistics custom_sei_possible Specify if the current stream can insert custom SEI custom_sei_buf_num Specify the custom sei buffer number in one stream custom sei buffer pool and only used when custom_sei_possible is 1 custom_sei_data_max_size Specify the maximum data size bytes for custom sei which is used for allocating memory in DSP and iav driver Example Typical Structure of Lua Configuration File There are three VOUT controllers in the CV5x CV72 SoC The VOUT Lua is required to correctly set up the VOUT controller ITEM Description status Selection 0 Disable 1 on 2 off 3 reset disable do not use this VOUT controller mode Specify VOUT format such as or input_yuv422 Specify if the input YUV format is YUV422 video_output_window Specify the output window in the format offset_x offset_y output_width output_heigh type Specify the valid VOUT type for each controller hdmi_output_format Specify the data format for HDMI output This is valid when the type is or vout_from_image Specify the flag for VOUT from the image default_image_format Specify the default image format This is valid when VOUT from the image is enabled video_rotate Specify the flag for enabling rotation for VOUT video_flip_mode Specify the flip mode for VOUT disable horizontal vertical horizontal vertical own_mixer Specify if the VOUT controller has a mixer osd_output_window Specify the onscreen display OSD output window of offset_x offset_y output_width output_heigh osd_flip_mode Specify the flip mode for OSD disable horizontal vertical horizontal vertical osd_rescaler Specify the flag to enable the OSD rescaler osd_rescaler_output_window Specify the OSD rescaler window of offset_x offset_y output_width output_heigh osd_transparent_color_enable Specify if the OSD rescaler tranparent color is enabled or not max_osd_bit_depth Specify the max OSD bit depth 0 auto 8 8 bits 1 6 1 6 bits 3 2 3 2 bits Example Hardware and Software Environment In order for this test case to function users must perform the following Insert the input sensor IMX274 with a mobile industry processor interface MIPIÂ® into the VIN0 slot Connect the EVK board to PC via a universal asynchronous receiver transmitter UART and Ethernet interface Connect a monitor to the HDMI interface Figure 7-1 Single VIN Hardware Connection Overview of the System Resources The following diagram is an overview of system resources for the current case For more details users can refer to the following Lua source file which is located in lua or lua Figure 7-2 Lua Configuration for Single VIN with 1080p Input First initialize the EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode and start 3 A statistics if the following command was not executed previously Set up the system resources with the Lua script Then set up three streams Stream_0 s encoding format is H.265 encoded from canvas 0 Stream_1 s encoding format is H.264 encoded from canvas 3 Stream_2 s encoding format is MJPEG encoded from canvas 2

BASIC Raw BASIC Raw CV5x chips process raw data from VINs in the unit of channel and support compressed uncompressed and unpacking uncompressed and packing raw data 1 compressed raw VIN is 1 0 8 0 p 2 uncompressed and unpacking raw VIN is 1 0 8 0 p 3 uncompressed and packing raw VIN is 1 0 8 0 p 1 2 bit Raw buffer is generated and reported to Arm by DSP and is allocated and maintained using two different methods In addition it can be configured through and item of channel cfg in the Lua script Raw buffer Auto-Generation Mode Raw buffer Manual-Feed Mode In raw buffer auto-generation mode DSP allocates and maintains the raw buffer Each time DSP captures raw data then it is automatically reported to Arm In auto-generation mode DSP will guarantee frame rate In raw buffer manual-feed mode frame queue is fully driven and controlled by user application Each time a user application requests a raw buffer it will trigger IAV driver feeds an empty buffer address to DSP DSP fills raw data into the buffers and then reports back to Arm See also 1.4 Pyramid Feed Mode Raw slice buffer can be configured through raw_slice_num and raw_slice_cached_items item of channel config in the Lua script When this feature is enabled DSP will slice RAW data vertically and evenly so that IDSP can process the slice of RAW data one by one Once the slice data is ready DSP will report the slice data to ARM and user application can capture the slice data of RAW For some special cases with large resolution DSP will need more time to process one frame If the RAW data can be sliced users will obtain the RAW data processed by DSP earlier Currently Cooper SDK has supported the different slice numbers such as 2 4 6 8 Users can configure the VIN raw via Lua script Here are the parameters for raw Item Parameter Description mode a x b Specify the VIN resolution bits 8 8 bits 1 0 1 0 bits 1 2 1 2 bits 1 4 1 4 bits 1 6 1 6 bits 0 Default bits Specify the VIN bits raw_capture 0 Raw compressed 1 Raw uncompressed Enable raw uncompressed packing_mode_enable 0 Raw packing disabled 1 Raw packing enabled Enable Raw packing only valid when raw_capture 1 An Example for VIN Raw Lua Configuration Here is an example for uncompressed raw buffer manual feed Specify and in lua

IQ Lite NN IQ Lite NN Version Updated Date Modification 0.0.1 2 0 2 4 0 1 2 4 Initial Version Lite NN includes vivid high dynamic range HDR neural network NN and true motion NN True motion uses NN to do motion detection to get more reliable and accurate motion estimation to help motion compensated temporal filtering MCTF to do a better job Vivid HDR uses NN to do tone mapping rather than the traditional contrast enhancement CE block This section introduces the usage of Lite NN by steps Image flow library doesnât support to load Lite NN automatically Users are required to enable Lite NN mode mannually Lite NN should be configured in product_config.lua which is parsed by test_aaa_service To set up the Lite NN follow the steps below Configure menuconfig Select img-lite-nn-datas For Cooper Amba build Preparation on board side before running Lite NN Copy lite NN bin files to the board path such as Update product_config.lua to select Lite NN type and its bin file path on evk lua Run Lite NN with sensor input Take true motion NN with IMX678 on CV72_gage board as an example This section introduces the basic idea of true motion Section 3.1 Introduction Section 3.2 ADJ Parameters Section 3.3 Invalid Parameters List True motion uses NN to do motion detection to get more reliable and accurate motion estimation to help MCTF to do a better job A sensitivity is open to describe the detection strength of different moving objects under different lighting conditions Motion detection neural network is applied in current NN model to allow the movement to be more accurately detected In auto adjust ADJ the releated filter is nn_md in fc_nn_pkg it includes the control of motion detection neural network The nn_md is applied in current NN model to allow movement to be more accurately detected Table 3 1 ADJ Parameters of True Motion Parameters Type Description ik_nn_md_t sensitivity unit 3 2 Range 0 1 2 8 As the sensitivity increases it becomes easier to identify motion of small objects and the detection area of motion becomes larger Due to the different relationship between the noise and motion of each sensor under each gain the MD_sensitivity can be set different value under each gain These two blocks will no longer take effect and instead the motion detection results will be taken from motion detection MD NN Motion_detect fc_motion_detect Table 3 2 ADJ Parameters of Motion detect Parameters Type Description enable uint32 1 for enable 0 for disable lev_add_1_method uint32 value 0 2 7 8 1 2 lev_add_1_table 6 4 uint32 array range 0 2 5 5 lev_add_2_method uint32 value 0 2 7 8 1 2 lev_add_2_table 6 4 uint32 array range 0 2 5 5 lev_mul_1_method uint32 value 0 2 7 8 1 2 lev_mul_1_table 6 4 uint32 array range 0 2 5 5 lev_mul_2_method uint32 value 0 2 7 8 1 2 lev_mul_2_table 6 4 uint32 array range 0 2 5 5 local_lighting uint32 range 0 1 motion_response uint32 range 1 5 1 1 noise_base uint32 range 0 4 0 9 5 slow_mo_sensitivity uint32 range 0 1 9 Motion_detect_and_mctf fc_motion_detect_and_mctf Table 3 3 ADJ Parameters of MCTF Parameters Type Description local_lighting_radius unit32 Range 0 6 8 The fc_motion_detect_pos_dep works with md_nn_mode y/cb/cr_temporal_alpha* and y/cb/cr_temporal_t* The valid T value greater than 1 is considered to the motion part The rest are consistent with MCTF usage of traditional image digital signal processing IDSP tuning guide This section introduces the basic idea of vivid HDR Section 4.1 Introduction Section 4.2 ADJ Parameters Vivid HDR uses NN to do tone mapping rather than the traditional CE block Table 4 1 ADJ Parameters of Vivid HDR Parameters Type Description f_ce_nn_alpha_beta_gamma alpha unit32 Range 0 2 5 5 f_ce_nn_alpha_beta_gamma beta unit32 Range 0 2 5 5 f_ce_nn_alpha_beta_gamma gamma unit32 Range 0 2 5 5 Section 5.1 Introduction Section 5.2 API Details Section 5.2.1 Common APIs for AISP and Lite NN Section 5.2.2 Unique APIs for AISP Section 5.2.3 Unique API for Lite NN library is an image middleware which is responsible for loading image signal processor ISP NN networks AISP and Lite NN and runtime selecting specified network based on 3 A related results Key nn_container_pkg part in ADJ file CE strength It is calculated based on shutter ratio result The calculation is as follow CE_strength Shutter_ratio 8 When CE_strength is greater than 2 5 5 it should be clipped to 2 5 5 Prepare IDSP stage Runtime update after entering preview This section content is still under construction Exit preview stage

ADVANCED Encode from Memory ADVANCED Encode from Memory This chapter describes the usage of encoding from the memory cases There are two main cases for this feature based on different processing stages inside the DSP Encode from RAW The input for DSP is in the form of RAW data either bayer RGB format or YUV format and it is fed into the VIN buffer Encode from MEM The input for the DSP is YUV YUV420 format with UV interleaved ME1 data and it is fed into the extended source buffer EFM buffer For the EFM case user memory partition is needed to transfer the RAW data configure it from as below Below size is 6 4 MB For Cooper SDK Amba build For Cooper SDK Yocto build Or use to allocate user buffer runtime For the encode from MEM case users should configure related settings through lua script first Here is part of lua as example For H.264 YUV and ME1 buffers are needed for the DSP If there is no ME1 test_efm will generate it automatically For H.265 YUV ME1 and ME0 buffers are needed for the DSP If there is no ME1 or ME0 test_efm will generate them automatically For MJPEG only YUV is needed for the DSP If only doing MJPEG encoding especially for high-resolution it is strongly suggested to set for the EFM stream through lua script This is to save certain DSP hardware resource in case running out of it Start EFM stream encoding it needs to run in another console right after to feed EFM buffer with specific YUV data continuously into the DSP Different from CV2x platform CV5x uses the ID 2 4 for EFM streams because CV5x supports up to 2 0 canvases So the ID 1 6 on CV5x actually means canvas with ID 1 6 and 2 4 stands for EFM buffer EFM stream supports overlay but doesn t support blur from EFM buffer Input from YUV NV12 file This is for debug usage channel 0 is for virtual vinc_id channel 1 is for EFM

BASIC Overlay on Streams BASIC Overlay on Streams Cooper family chips use overlay hardware to superimpose graphical and/or textual information on video streams With the CV overlay function the video is encoded with extra YUV data which results in overlay data format in YUV To display the overlay data DSP refers to a color look-up table CLUT to obtain the correct color The memory is mapped to the application filled with the CLUT information and OSD data The total memory size depends on the chip version Overlay Source Buffer The overlay is inserted directly into the source buffer associated with the encoded stream Adding an overlay when the streams are encoding from the same canvas can cause an overlay flickering or For example if both stream A and B encode from the canvas with the main buffer the overlay inserted on stream A will also be shown on stream B and vice versa If stream B s frame rate does not match stream A s the result can be a loss of OSD in the frames on stream B causing an overlay flickering effect Therefore if users require to perform overlay blending with more than one stream while avoiding overlay leakage Ambarella recommends encoding the streams from separate source buffers and configuring overlays for each stream Color Look-up Table Cooper family chips support 1 6 independent color look-up tables CLUT Only CLUT8 mode is supported Each CLUT requires 1 KB of memory With CLUT8 each look-up table is an array of 2 5 6 entries The entry is defined for four individual channels Y U V and alpha transparency Alpha 0 is transparent and 2 5 5 is non-transparent Coordinate Position Size The coordinate space of the overlay window is the same as that of the stream The following figure shows the overlay area position and size Overlay Area Position and Size For each overlay area the following restrictions are mandatory The overlay width and height cannot be zero The overlay cannot exceed the boundary of the stream The width/height and horizontal/vertical offset of the overlay area must be a multiple of 4 The buffer pitch of the overlay area is suggested to be aligned to 6 4 bytes for high DRAM transferring efficiency The total overlay size of all the streams should be no larger than the half of the mapped memory size For all streams up to 6 4 overlay areas are supported Rotated Overlay Because rotation and flip are performed after overlay insertion the overlay rotates or flips with the stream To display the overlay in the orientation of the stream the offset/width/height of the overlay region should be calculated according to rotation degree and the overlay data should be transformed by a rotation matrix The following figures show the overlay on the stream and the overlay buffer before clockwise rotations Rotated Overlay Multiple Buffering To prevent cache pollution use the multiple buffering strategy to update overlay content The buffer number is determined by the updating frequency The following describes when a user assumes that overlay is updated every N frames Double Buffering N 5 For example in real time overlay display the time string is updated every second The frequency is much greater than 5 frames Quad buffering N 5 For example using overlay as time stamp every frame has different overlay content The frequency is 1 frame Insert Always means that the overlay is inserted into every captured frame without taking into consideration if the encode frame factor is being used This feature is used to prevent overlay leakage when different streams with distinct frame factors are encoded from the same source buffer The following is an example scenario in which two streams are encoding from the same source buffer Both stream A and B are encoding from the main source buffer Stream A s frame rate is 3 0 and stream B s frame rate is 1 5 If the insert overlay to stream B with flag is enabled stream A will also contain the overlay in all frames Alternatively if the insert overlay with is not enabled the overlay content will not appear in every frame from stream A causing stream A to appear as if it contains flash overlay content Text Language Support Because many languages such as Chinese and Japanese use character sets larger than the range of values of type char the GNU C library includes support for extended character sets Follow this link for details on the GNU C extended characters Wide Character The text insert package of the CV5x Flexible Linux SDK requires characters to be represented as wide characters As a result users must convert Chinese and other languages to the wide character type before using the text insert package Character Set The behavior of the function is affected by the current locale Users should install the character set and set it up before calling the function Locales can be found in the toolchain folder linaro-aarch64-2018.08 Put the required locale to on the CV5x board Before the function call setlocale to set the current locale Reboot the EVK board and then set up a stream on the EVK board Set up three rectangle overlay areas Three Rectangles Overlay on One Stream Update the Overlay Area Clear all overlays for multiple streams Reboot the EVK board and then set up 2 streams on the EVK board Update the Overlay Every Frame
S stream 0 Specify stream ID S stream 0 Specify stream ID
d data SEI data in format data1 x data2 d data SEI data in format data1 x data2
p pts-sync 0 Enable/disable PTS sync for custom SEI insertion p pts-sync 0 Enable/disable PTS sync for custom SEI insertion
R random-size Enable random custom SEI data size R random-size Enable random custom SEI data size
r repeat insert SEI repeatedly in all encoded frames r repeat insert SEI repeatedly in all encoded frames

BASIC Privacy Mask BASIC Privacy Mask Privacy mask PM is used to block sensitive areas covering them with opaque single-color boxes in both the preview and the encoded streams Privacy mask is widely used for displays keyboard sequences such as passwords and anywhere else where sensitive information needs to be kept invisible It is possible to retrieve the blocked-out areas during the preview and encoding states Cooper family chips support privacy mask The privacy mask take effect on the video input VIN domain The precision of the single-color privacy mask varies according to the different VIN Main combinations The color of the single-color privacy mask can be changed to various Y U V combinations Privacy mask affects all views from the preview third fourth fifth buffer and the encoded streams main second third fourth fifth seventh buffer Configurable Color of Single-Color Privacy Mask It is possible to set it to various Y U V combinations Number of Mask Area The number of masks is unlimited Size of Mask Area The maximum size of masks is up to the VIN size In privacy mask design the concept of three domains need to be clear including VIN domain main domain and PM domain is the whole VIN capture window is Main source buffer output window and is the window that finally draws PM in memory When users need to draw PM only coordinates and sizes on the are specified But actually it needs to be converted to the coordinates and sizes on the In most cases and are the same size In particular if there is rotate or flip enabled needs to be converted from For example in the case of rotate the width and height of are the height and width of The usual way to deal with PM PM coordinate and size convert is Figure 1 1 VIN Main and PM Domain Conversion Diagram Add two privacy mask areas x 1 0 0 y 1 0 0 width 2 5 6 height 2 5 6 x 4 0 0 y 2 0 0 width 1 2 8 height 6 4 to 1 0 8 0 p Figure 2-1 Privacy Mask Setting Remove a privacy mask area x 1 6 4 y 1 6 4 width 1 2 8 height 1 2 8 from the privacy mask region x 1 0 0 y 1 0 0 width 2 5 6 height 2 5 6 Figure 2-2 Privacy Mask Remove a Privacy Mask Area Insert circular inner privacy mask circle center point is 9 6 0 5 4 0 the radius is 5 4 4 Figure 2-3 Single-Color Privacy Mask Insert Circular Inner Privacy Mask Insert circular outer privacy mask circle center point is 9 6 0 5 4 0 the radius is 5 4 4 Figure 2-4 Single-Color Privacy Mask Insert Circular Outer Privacy Mask Insert triangle privacy mask triangle vertex is 3 0 0 5 0 0 1 0 0 0 9 0 0 1 5 0 0 4 0 0 Figure 2-5 Single-Color Privacy Mask Insert Triangle Privacy Mask Insert quadrilateral privacy mask quadrilateral vertex is 2 0 0 3 0 0 1 5 0 5 0 0 8 0 0 6 0 0 1 0 0 0 4 0 0 Figure 2-6 Single-Color Privacy Mask Insert Quadrilateral Privacy Mask For this use case users can easily specify the PM offset and size in canvas domain through test_privacymask The PM can cover the areas from one or multiple channels When the PM areas cross multiple channels test_privacymask will convert the coordinates of the canvas domain to the coordinates of the main buffer for each channel Comparing with the use experience where users need to manually calculate the coordinates of PM for each channel this method is much easier to configure For example to add one privacy mask area x 2 6 0 0 y 5 0 0 width 1 0 0 0 height 9 0 0 The Lua script can be found here Figure 2-7 Single-Color Privacy Mask Insert Canvas domain Privacy Mask When using LDC the frame border may get some repeat artifacts Users can fill and cover it with privacy mask According to the DSP warp pipeline behavior privacy mask will be processed after H-Warp and before V-Warp As the H-warp edge is different in different warp case the H-warp edge mask is needed then privacy mask can fill the repeat artifact with the mask The LDC example case shows as below Figure 2-8 Frame Border Artifact Prepare the mask YUV In mask YUV border can be filled with black(0) and others can be filled with white(255) Then feed this mask YUV as VIN by using feature EFR Example 5 Encode from YUV NV12 RAW: YUV NV12 RAW to VIN Capture the H-Warp only YUV for final mask Run the LDC case again and using test_privacymask with final mask YUV Figure 2-9 Original Mask YUV Figure 2-10 Mask YUV with H-Warp Figure 2-11 Fill Frame Border Privacy Mask with Mask YUV This feature can only be used in LDC warp case not for multi-region warp case

BASIC Channel BASIC Channel Channel is the software concept of the image digital signal processing IDSP pipeline For each channel CV5x chips process the input frames captured from a RGB sensor or YUV device and generate different YUV buffers for further processing The supported channels are up to eight In the IDSP pipeline there are two major stages RAW processing stage and YUV processing stage In the RAW processing stage IDSP has high dynamic range HDR blending module to blend multiple exposures into a single frame various filters for noise reduction and color enhancement and finally color convertion module to convert RGB format to YUV format In the YUV processing stage IDSP has filters for color noise reduction and enhancement the module for warp and scale functions the motion-compensated temporal filtering MCTF module for 3 D noise reduction and the module for final sharpen processing For each channel the RGB or YUV RAW frames will go through the entire IDSP pipeline to generate source buffers So when there are some features turned off in the IDSP pipeline the RAW frames still go through the entire pipeline but the data will pass through some filters or modules without any processing For example YUV RAW data will still go through the RAW processing pipeline but it may pass through these modules inside the RAW processing stage with the data unchanged in this stage Channel IDSP Pipeline For CV2x chips there is a dedicated encode mode 3 for IDSP rotation and flip operations However for CV5x CV7x chips the rotation and flip operations can be supported in different encode modes such as encode mode 0 and encode mode 5 Therefore this dedicated encode mode 3 is no longer needed for CV5x CV7x chips There is a dedicated parameter rotate_cw in channel configurations to achieve 9 0 degree clockwise rotation The parameter hflip in channel configurations is to achieve horizontal flip and the paramter vflip in channel configurations is to achieve vertical flip The following is the resource configuration Channel Rotation Configurations Configurations Description rotate_cw 1 9 0 degree clockwise rotation hflip 1 vflip 1 1 8 0 degree clockwise rotation rotate_cw 1 hflip 1 vflip 1 2 7 0 degree clockwise rotation Channel Rotation Flip Limitations for channel rotation flip are as follows For rotation Main Buffer must be 1 6 aligned for width and 3 2 aligned for height For flip there is no special alignment requirement It is the same as no flip cases For CV5x chips there are two indepenndet IDSP cores to process RAW frames from input RAW frames For these two IDSP cores users can be able to configure different Core modes for different channels There are three IDSP core modes for users to configure for each channel The first is to enable IDSP core 0 only for the channel The second is to enable IDSP core 1 only for the channel The last one is to enable both IDSP cores for the channel By default all channels are configured with IDSP dual cores But this is not most efficient way for all use cases For the single VIN with 8 K senor input it is highly recommended to enable both IDSP cores to the channel in order to achieve the best performance by fully utilizing both cores For the multiple VIN use cases it is more recommended to use single core for each channel when the use cases are symmetric For example there are four sensor inputs and each is with 4 Kp30 IDSP performance For such use case it is highly recommended to use independent IDSP cores for each channel which means two channels with IDSP core 0 and other two channels with IDSP core 1 This is more efficient than IDSP dual cores because IDSP dual cores may have performance overhead caused by dual core performance balancing For CV72 there is only one IDSP core MCTF compression is used to compress MCTF reference frames to achieve better dynamic random access memory DRAM performance There is a param in iav_chan_cfg to configure this By default it is enabled And users may need to tune MCTF compression bitrate related parameters to achieve best image quality When it is turned off more DRAM bandwidth is needed for IDSP processing so it may be expected the overall performance may be slightly lower than the same case when it is turned on For the IDSP virtual channel use case IDSP virtual channels send 3 A configurations to IDSP separately from its master channel Due to the excution latency of 3 A application sometimes the virtual channels might not be frame-synchronized with the sensor shutter/gain settings As a result there will be artifacts on IDSP virtual channels Therefore Ambarella provides the reuse_src_chan_iso_cfg parameter in lua scripts to do the frame synchronization When this option reuse_src_chan_iso_cfg is enabled the current IDSP virtual channel will use duplicated 3 A configuration of master channel to achieve same and frame-synchronized settings as the master channel This option is only valid when current channel is IDSP virtual channel and sensor control is disabled First initialize the EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode and start 3 A process if the following command was not executed previously Next in this lua script case modify the channel related configurations Enable the rotate_cw flag to enable 9 0 degree clockwise rotation Set the Main Buffer width corresponding to the VIN height and align to 1 6 Set the Main Buffer height corresponding to the VIN width and align to 3 2 Adjust other canvas buffer sizes if needed due to the rotation on Main Buffer Use video output VOUT rotate flip to view the image data before rotation First initialize the EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode and start 3 A process if the following command was not executed previously Modify the lua file for Channel IDSP horizontal and vertical flip First initialize the EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode and start 3 A process if the following command was not executed previously Modify the lua file to enable IDSP dual core configuration and enable core 0 here First initialize the EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode and start 3 A process if the following command was not executed previously Modify the lua file for reuse_src_chan_iso_cfg For idsp virtual channel with sensor_ctrl disabled and reuse_src_chan_iso_cfg enabled not suggested to specify img_stats_src_chan to itself It is only for IDSP processing with different IDSP config based on each channel s own 3 A statistics virtual_channel_duplicate_3A.lua This feature also applies to CV72 in the same way

BASIC Video Ouput BASIC Video Ouput CV5x CV72 has three video output VOUT controllers VOUT A VOUT B and VOUT C VOUT A and VOUT B support mobile industry processor interface MIPI CSIÂ® and MIPI DSI VOUT C supports high-definition multimedia interface HDMIÂ® and composite video broadcast signal CVBS The maximum resolution of VOUT A is 4 K The maximum resolution of VOUT B and VOUT C is 8 K Pipeline for VOUT For CV5x chips there are two VOUT mixers for VOUT A and for VOUT B/C This means that VOUT B and C shares the same VOUT mixer For CV72 chip there are three VOUT mixers for VOUT A and for VOUT B and for VOUT C VOUT mixer A is affiliated with VOUT A and VOUT mixer B is affiliated with VOUT B For CV5x CV7x platforms there is no requirement to reuse the VOUT mixer for other purposes including stream blur The two VOUT mixers are used only by VOUT modules themselves VOUT default image is used to display user-specified image It can support either YUV422(NV16) or YUV420(NV12) image format When this feature is enabled users are not required to specify type canvas for VOUT See Example 4 VOUT Default Image VOUT rotate is used to run-time rotate the input image at the VOUT stage When the input resolution is width x height the VOUT output resolution is height x width The final display resolution is also height x width See Example 5 VOUT Rotate for typical cases Rotate VOUT size and rotate state support changes on the fly If users must change the VOUT size they should change corresponding buffer size before VOUT size See example_vout_rotate_change_on_the_fly for such cases One typical use case for the VOUT rotate feature is used together with the image digital signal processor IDSP rotate feature.The input image is already pre-rotated at the IDSP stage Users can use the VOUT rotate feature to rotate the pre-rotated image and to display the unrotated image For example when IDSP rotate is used the VOUT input size may be 7 2 0 x1280 With VOUT rotate enabled the VOUT output size would be 1 2 8 0 x720 The final display size is also 1 2 8 0 x720 See example_vout_rotate_mode3 for such cases Only progressive VOUT mode can support rotation The VOUT rotate feature may require some extra digital signal processor DSP internal resources VOUT rotate must set an aligned correspond preview buffer size in the Lua file VOUT rotate 1 0 8 0 p requires a 1 0 8 8 x1920 preview buffer VOUT flip is used to flip images horizontally or vertically It can flip the video or on-screen display OSD See Example 6 VOUT Flip for typical cases For some scenarios users may be required to configure VOUT input when entering the preview state without the VOUT module configured Users may enable the VOUT module and the display unit on the fly at later stages From the DSP perspective VOUT input data format configuration may be independent from VOUT procedure and output configuration Users may be required to ensure that the VOUT input format matches the VOUT output format Otherwise the video output may be corrupted The HDMI controller on CV5x CV72 systems on chip SoCs can support output RGB YUV422 and YUV444 formats Normally VOUT will be switched off when the IDSP is in the idle state and VOUT will be reset after entering into the preview state again In this case VOUT must be reconfigured again after the idle state For some scenarios may be required to enable VOUT at all times even when IDSP is in the idle state For example users can configure a VOUT on-screen display OSD on the display while performing mode switch between the DSP idle state and preview state in the background In this case VOUT OSD is active all the time while the VOUT video layer is switched between the live sensor input image in the preview state and the VOUT background color in the idle state From the DSP perspective the VOUT module is independent from the IDSP VDSP modules This makes it possible to have VOUT functioning with IDSP in the idle state separately In this case the VOUT input source will be switched to the VOUT background color When IDSP is switched to the preview state VOUT can switch the input source back to the live sensor input See Example 8 VOUT No Reset for Mode Switch for typical cases Users can use vout osd frame sync to allows the osd content of each frame can be precisely synchronized with the frame displayed by vout See Example 9 VOUT OSD Sync for typical cases The Cooper chip family supports multiple VOUT interfaces including the following HDMI v2.0 output including on-chip PHY with consumer electronic control CEC support HDMI output resolution is up to 8 KP60 no period 4 lane MIPI DSI CSI output no period Video digital-to-analog converter DAC for 4 8 0 i 5 7 6 i composite PAL NTSC output Full screen frame buffer on the analog digital video output The table below lists the supported VOUT Interfaces for each chip in the Cooper family VOUT Interface CV5 CV52 CV72 HDMI Yes Yes Yes CVBS Yes Yes Yes MIPI_DSI Yes Yes Yes MIPI_CSI Yes Yes Yes First initialize the evaluation kit EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode and begin 3 A AE AWB AF statistics if the following command was not executed previously Output Resolution Control HDMI with 4 8 0 p resolution Modification of vout_hdmi.lua file for 4 8 0 p HDMI with 7 2 0 p resolution HDMI with 1 0 8 0 p resolution Disable VOUT First initialize the EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode then start 3 A statistics if the following command was not executed previously Video Output 4 8 0 i CVBS HDMI output size can be changed while encoding or during preview without changing back to the idle state Before issuing the change command the preview buffer must be configured to the new output size VOUT change on the fly in decoding is not supported Configure the platform to build test_custom_vout 1 Display YUV420 NV12 Image File through VOUT Default Image Function Configure VOUT Lua option to enable VOUT default image function and configure VOUT Lua option is to set image format to YUV420(NV12) 2 Display YUV420 NV12 Canvas in Live through VOUT Default Image Function Configure VOUT Lua option to enable VOUT default image function and configure VOUT Lua option is to set image format to YUV420(NV12) test_custom_vout option is used to specify canvas id First initialize the EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode then start 3 A process if the following command was not executed previously Next in this lua script case modify the preview buffer size Set the buffer width corresponding to the VOUT height and align to 3 2 Set the buffer height corresponding to the VOUT width and align to 1 6 First initialize the EVK board to load the essential drivers and microcode then start 3 A process if the following command was not executed previously Modification of vout_hdmi.lua file for VOUT flip Modification of vout_hdmi.lua file for VOUT OSD flip Modification of vout_hdmi.lua file for HDMI outputs This feature is designed to keep VOUT active at all times during mode switch The option is used to enable the option for no-VOUT reset when putting DSP into the idle state or preview state Modification of vout_hdmi.lua file for maximum OSD bit depth Modification of vout_hdmi.lua file for maximum OSD bit depth Update for the preview type canvas Modification of vout_hdmi.lua file to turn on the DSI output via vout_0 Updating option vout_id of the preview canvas in the cv72_vin0_1080p_linear.lua After the above preparation the following steps can launch this feature Modification of vout_hdmi.lua file to turn on the CSI output via vout_0 Updating option vout_id of the preview canvas in the cv72_vin0_1080p_linear.lua Dual Vout is a combination of two individual Vout devices in general Select vout_0 and vout_2 to take an example for this feature There are two preview type canvas as the resource of vout_id 0 and 2 CV72 HDMI is assigned by voutid 2 and can be as the one of dual VOUT the other can use lcd_r69429 which is assigned by voutid 0 The VOUT source is able to bind to different channel so user can switch input source of VOUT on the fly For an example below changes in cv72_vin0_1080p_linear.lua can support for this feature User can activate two vin as the video source for two channels vsrc_0 and vsrc_1 in this example bind to channel 1 and channel 2 respectively The fourth buffer within both channels will be set into preview canvas The following commands are for VOUT switch Setting vout-underflow-prevention value to improve VOUT priority that can avoid some display exceptions such as artifacts and flicking in VOUT This option has impact on the other modules DMA priority especially when the device is almost overloaded

BASIC GOP BASIC GOP Before GOP Group of Pictures introduction the table below is a simple description for different frame types The encode priority is I Q P B C D Frame Type Description I frame The key I frame Q frame Important P frame such as fast seek P long term P and some special encoded P frames P frame Normal P frame when using simple GOP Level 0 P frame when using SVC-T GOP B frame Normal B frame when using simple GOP Level 1 P frame when using SVC-T GOP C frame Level 2 P frame when using SVC-T GOP D frame Level 3 P frame when using SVC-T GOP Different GOP model means different reference relationship for P frame These GOP models as below are supported GOP Model Description Simple GOP 1 ref P without fast-seek Fast seek GOP 1 ref P with fast-seek Two ref GOP 2 ref P 2 short-ref or short-ref long-ref without fast-seek Fast seek with 2 ref GOP 2 ref P short-ref long-ref with fast-seek 2 level SVC-T GOP Scalable video coding temporal GOP with 2 layer 3 level SVC-T GOP Scalable video coding temporal GOP with 3 layer The default encode core mode is which only supports SVC-T GOP Users need to set the core mode as or to run other GOPs For more dual core mode usage please refer 1.14 Encoder Dual Cores For CV72 there is only one VDSP core so only with core 0 is supported The reference relationship in a GOP for a simple reference without B frame is shown below The Reference Relationship in the GOP for Single Reference without B Frame Simple GOP needs to work with dual encode core configurations as below The Lua script can be found here The reference relationship in a GOP for a simple reference with B frame is shown below The Reference Relationship in the GOP for a Single Reference with B Frame The reference relationship in a GOP for simple references with a fast seek is shown below The Reference Relationship in the GOP for a Single Reference with Fast Seek Important rules for this GOP structure The fast seek P frame will take the I IDR frame as a reference The normal P frame will take the I IDR or fast seek P frame as a reference B frame M 1 is not supported in fast-seek GOP The fast seek interval can be changed on the fly There is a special case of fast seek GOP structure if every P frame is fast seek P it means all P frames are referenced from the I IDR frames This is like the GOP structure The Reference Relationship of non-ref-P GOP fast-seek-interval 1 Two references for P frame 2 Ref is an advanced feature Traditionally one reference is used for each P frame and this reference frame is used as the short term reference In order to get a better video quality the I/IDR frame is added to the reference frame list for each P frame and treated as the long term reference frame The long term reference is used by the encoder to encode the static background areas and the short-term reference is used to encode the motion areas The reference relationship in a GOP for two simple reference cases is as follows The Reference Relationship in the GOP for Simple 2 Reference Important rules for this feature The rate control RC is enabled by digital signal processor DSP for this feature which means that DSP runs the bitrate control method to meet the target bitrate as much as possible The supported resolution must be no larger than 1 0 8 0 P due to more internal resources used by DSP in 2 ref over single ref Stream rotation is not supported together with this feature as more internal resources are used by DSP The reference relationship in a GOP for two short term reference cases is as follows The Reference Relationship in the GOP for 2 Short Term References Important rule for this feature There are two reference frames for each P frame the reference frame are I/IDR/P frame For the 2 reference short term GOP max-gop-M must be set as 3 Only 2 ref mode is supported with fast seek GOP The advanced two reference cases combine the simple two reference cases together with both fast seek and B frame The reference relationship in a GOP for the advanced two references case is shown below The Reference Relationship in the GOP for 2 Ref with Fast-Seek No B Frames Cases The advanced two reference cases are as follows There is only one reference frame for fast seek P frame and the reference frame is I/IDR frame Fast seek function can be implemented based on this single reference relationship For the remaining P frames normal P frames there are two reference frames One is the previous P frame which is used as a short-term reference frame for motion area encoding the other is I/IDR frame which is used as a long-term reference frame for static area encoding B frames are inserted into the reference frames I/IDR frame normal P frame and fast seek P frame Important rules for this feature The supported resolution must be no larger than 1 0 8 0 P due to more internal resources used by DSP in two-references than a single reference Stream rotation is not supported together with this feature due to more internal resources used by DSP The advanced two reference features are supported in mode 0 RC is not enabled for fast seek P frame which may cause bitrate issue The application needs to take the responsibility to do rate control from the ArmÂ® side The Reference Relationship in the GOP for 2 Ref with fast-seek 2 B Frames Cases SVC-T is an advanced feature Scalable video coding SVC standardizes the encoding of a high-quality video bit stream that also contains one or more subset bit streams There are several ways to implement SVC such as temporal scalability frame rate spatial scalability picture size and quality scalability picture quality Hierarchical P GOP supports up to three layers enabling CV5x to encode multiple layers with different reference frames to form a single bit stream As a rate control tool Hierarchical P GOP divides the video bit stream into several layers Because frames in higher layers can reference frames in lower layers while frames in lower layers cannot reference frames in higher layers higher layers can be discarded without affecting lower layers A player that supports SVC-T feature can decide which higher video layers needs to be discarded and decode the rest of the video layers In order to support SVC-T the application must use a proper N and GOP structure for streams to encode The following figure is a typical example for three layers Frames in Layer 2 are not referenced by any frame in any other layers so this layer can be discarded directly without affecting other layers Frames in Layer 1 are referenced by frames in Layer 2 so the decoder can discard this layer when Layer 2 is already discarded Layer 0 is referenced by all the other layers and it cannot be discarded Two Layers Hierarchical P GOP Structure Three Layers Hierarchical P GOP Structure There are some limitations for this GOP B frames are not supported which means that M must keep the value of 1 For CV5x SVC-T 2 can only work with mode For CV72 SVC-T 2 works with For CV5x SVC-T 3 HEVC can work with enc_core_mode 0 or enc_core_mode 3 For CV72 SVC-T 3 HEVC can work with For CV5x SVC-T 3 AVC can only work with enc_core_mode 0 For CV72 SVC-T 3 AVC can only work with SVC-T 3 GOP needs to work with dual encode core configurations Fast seek feature is added to 2 layers of SVC-T GOP structure this feature Below is the reference relation for SVC-T 2 layers GOP structure with the fast seek 2 Layers SVC-T Fast Seek Fast Seek Interval 4 To separate layer fast seek information in the encoded video NALU syntax for both AVC and HEVC is used to achieve this 3 Layers SVC-T Fast Seek Fast Seek Interval 8 For AVC syntax in NALU header is used to separate different layers and fast seek frames For above figure the fast seek interval is 8 for 3 layers SVC-T There are 4 different values For IDR/I frames and fast seek P frames red and green nal_ref_idc 3 For Blue Level 0 frames nal_ref_idc 2 For Yellow Level 1 frames nal_ref_idc 1 For Purple Level 2 frames nal_ref_idc 0 For HEVC syntax in NALU header is used to separate different layers and fast seek frames For above figure the fast seek interval is 8 for 3 layers SVC-T There are 4 different values For IDR/I frames and fast seek P frames red and green nuh_temporal_id_plus1 1 For Blue Level 0 frames nuh_temporal_id_plus1 2 For Yellow Level 1 frames nuh_temporal_id_plus1 3 For Purple Level 2 frames nuh_temporal_id_plus1 4

BASIC Pyramid BASIC Pyramid CV5x CV72 chips support pyramid generation for video content analysis VCA and support up to 7 layers of pyramid buffers Each layer of pyramid can be enable/disable independently The data format of each pyramid layer is YUV420 NV12 Pyramid Block Diagram The pyramid is generated from one of the source buffers Users can choose the pyramid input from the main buffer or one of the sub buffers If Layer 0 of the pyramid is enabled data from the input buffer will be copied to the buffer of pyramid Layer 0 In addition the size of pyramid Layer 0 is the same as the pyramid input buffer Ambarella recommends using the sub buffer as the input for the pyramid buffer as this can save DRAM bandwidth When main buffer is specified as pyramid input buffer it can also be used for encoding When sub source buffer is specified as pyramid input buffer it cannot be used for neither encoding nor VOUT preview In addition to Layer 0 there are two types of downsampling rate to determine the pyramid sizes For the first one each layer width height is 1 2 of the previous layer s width height for the second one each layer width height is 1 of the previous layer s size For example suppose that the pyramid input buffer is the fifth buffer with the size 1 2 8 0 x 7 2 0 The output of the pyramid layout is as follows Pyramid Layout Table Layer sqrt 2 1 Input 1 2 8 0 x 7 2 0 Layer 0 1 2 8 0 x 7 2 0 Same as the input buffer Layer 1 9 0 6 x 5 1 0 6 4 0 x 3 6 0 Layer 2 6 4 0 x 3 6 0 3 2 0 x 1 8 0 Layer 3 4 5 6 x 2 5 6 1 6 0 x 9 0 Layer 4 3 2 0 x 1 8 0 8 0 x 4 6 Layer 5 2 2 8 x 1 2 8 4 0 x 2 4 Layer 6 1 6 0 x 9 0 2 0 x 1 2 The full size for each pyramid layer is determined by the Layer 0 size and the scale type However users can specify the cropped window from the full pyramid layer size Users can also specify the ROI region as the cropped window and perform VCA based on this ROI This can also save DRAM bandwidth Each group of pyramid buffers is generated and reported to ArmÂ® by the digital signal processor DSP and is allocated and maintained using three different methods Additionally it can be configured through manual_feed item or item in the Lua script In the pyramid auto-generation mode pyramid buffers cannot be accessed by the VP In the pyramid manual feed mode and pyramid external-memory mode pyramid buffers can be accessed by the VP Pyramid Auto-Generation Mode Pyramid Manual-Feed Mode Pyramid External-Memory Mode In the pyramid auto-generation mode DSP allocates and maintains the pyramid buffers Each time DSP generates a group of pyramid buffers the group is automatically reported to Arm which uses the buffers to perform the video content analysis VCA However this method has two disadvantages When Arm receives the pyramid buffers it copies them to additional memory to prevent data from being overwritten in case the user s application VCA algorithm is insufficient DSP reuses the pyramid buffers several frames later Copying the data requires extra the dynamic random-access memory DRAM size bandwidth and CPU cycles Because of the processing speed of the VCA algorithm user applications typically fetch pyramid buffers at a lower fps however DSP generates pyramid buffers according to its own processing speed As a result more DRAM bandwidth are required for DSP to generate extra pyramid buffers To avoid the potential disadvantages of using the pyramid auto-generation mode Ambarella recommends using the pyramid manual-feed mode instead The pyramid manual-feed mode enables Arm to allocate and maintain the pyramid buffers Each time an user application requests a group of pyramid buffers it feeds an empty group to DSP DSP fills pyramid data into the buffers and then reports back to Arm Because Arm is responsible for the maintaining the pyramid buffers not feeding them to the DSP before they have been processed is to avoid data overwriting Additionally Arm does not need to copy the pyramid buffers into its local memory and it can control the feeding rate of pyramid buffers making it unnecessary for DSP to generate pyramid buffers at the image digital signal processing IDSP fps Due to these advantages including reducing the DRAM bandwidth Ambarella recommends using the pyramid manual-feed mode for user applications In the pyramid external-memory mode Arm allocates the pyramid buffers and DSP maintains these pyramid buffers These pyramid buffers can be accessed by the VP Each time DSP generates a group of pyramid buffers the group is automatically reported to Arm Because of CV5x and CV72 s special architecture VP cannot access the pyramid memory in the pyramid auto-generation mode If the user wants the DSP to maintain the pyramid buffers and also VP can access these buffers then the pyramid external-memory mode is a good choice For the pyramid input users can choose an arbitrary size instead of the input buffer size To choose an arbitrary size users would apply the digital zoom operation from the pyramid s input buffer to the pyramid Layer 1 The pyramid Layer 0 is the same size as the pyramid input buffer Therefore there are a maximum of six available pyramid layers The latter pyramid layers size are down-sampled with the fixed ratio of 2 the ratio of sqrt 2 is no longer supported See the following figure for a diagram of choosing an arbitrary pyramid size Arbitrary Pyramid Size For pyramid layers it is only supports arbitrary downscaling from Layer 0 to Layer 1 The downscaling ratio can be various from 1 inclusive to 1 exclusive Please check Pyramid Configuration for more information Users can configure the pyramid via Lua script Here is the parameters for pyramid Item Parameter Description input_buf_id 0 Main Buffer 1 Second Buffer 2 Third Buffer 3 Fourth Buffer 4 Fifth Buffer Specifying the input source buffer ID in this channel scale_type 0 Downsampled by sqrt 2 1 Downsampled by 2 2 Arbitrary Scale Specifying the paramid downsampling rate buf_addr Physical Address Specifying the external buffer address in pyramid auto-generation mode It is 0 when pyramid is from DSP internal buffer In pyramid manual-feed mode it must be 0 as its pyramid buffer pool is allocated by IAV driver buf_size buf_size 0 In pyramid auto-generation mode it is used to specify the total external buffer size to store all pyramid layers It is valid only when the is specified This total buffer size should include up to 7 layers with 4 x 8 x for circular usage In pyramid manual-feed mode it can also be used to specify a fixed pyramid buffer pool size When it is specified IAV driver won t reallocate pyramid buffer pool again even if the really required pool size is changed frame_rate 0 frame_rate idsp_fps Specify the pyramid frame rate it must be less than idsp_fps This feature is not yet supported manual_feed 0 Pyramid Auto-generation Mode 1 Pyramid Manual-feed Mode Enable pyramid manual-feed mode item_num 4 1 2 Specifying the number of the manual feed or external buffers This value should be in the range of 4 1 2 If lower than 4 it will be set to 4 by IAV driver If higher than 1 2 it will be set to 1 2 by IAV driver If value is 0 it will be set to the default value 6 rescale_size width height Specifying rescale size for pyramid Layer 1 The scale ratio of width or height from Layer 0 to Layer 1 must be in the range of 1 X to 8 X Downscale The scale ratio from Layer N N 1 5 to Layer N+1 is fixed to 2 X Downscale Only valid when max_rescale_size width height Specifying max rescale size for pyramid Layer 1 Used to set the max rescale size of pyramid Layer 1 must be within Only valid when layer_map Bits map Specifying bits map for pyramid layers one bit for one layer eg bit 0 means layer 0 bit 1 means layer 1 bit 6 means layer 6 can be changed dynamically To enable all 7 layers set this value to 0 x7F max_layer_map Bits map Specifying max bits map for pyramid layers one bit for one layer eg bit 0 means layer 0 bit 1 means layer 1 bit 6 means layer 6 can only be changed before entering preview must be within crop_win offset_x offset_y width height Specifying the output window of pyramid buffer from each layer The default value 0 0 0 0 means the pyramid layer s active window without cropping rather than the window with size 0 x0 enable_frame_tag 0 disable 1 enable Enable pyramid frame-tag frame_tag_value 0 0 xFFFFFFFF Specifying frame tag value Only valid when enable_frame_tag is enabled frame_tag_mask 0 0 xFFFFFFFF Specifying bitmask of frame tag Only valid when enable_frame_tag is enabled Note frame_tag_mask must meet the condition frame_tag_mask frame_tag_value frame_tag_value ext_mem 0 Default disable 1 enable is used to enable pyramid external memory mode Set to 1 to enable pyramid external memory An Example for Pyramid Lua Configuration See Configure with Lua Script Pyramid can be captured by user application Here pyramid data from Layer 0 to Layer 6 will be captured by test_yuvcap The following is the resource configuration Resource Configure Item Description Sensor IMX274_MIPI 3 8 4 0 x 2 1 6 0 Pyramid Input Third Buffer 1 9 2 0 x 1 0 8 0 Scale Type scale_type 0 Pyramid downsampling ratio will be sqrt 2 Feed Mode manual_feed 0 Auto-genetation mode Pyramid Layer Map layer_map 0 x7F Enable the pyramid from Layer 0 to Layer 6 Test steps are as follows The following is a full set of the captured pyramid Capture Pyramid Data In lua file pyramid parameters and should be set to support feeding the pyramid manually The following is the resource configuration Resource Configure Item Description Sensor IMX274_MIPI 1 9 2 0 x 1 0 8 0 Pyramid Input Main Buffer 1 9 2 0 x 1 0 8 0 Scale Type scale_type 1 Pyramid downsampling ratio will be 2 Feed Mode manual_feed 1 Enable pyramid manual feed Pyramid Buffer Item item_num 6 Buffer alloced by IAV for pyramid manual feed are set to 6 Pyramid Layer Map layer_map 0 x2f Enable pyramid Layer0 Layer1 Layer2 Layer3 and Layer5 Test steps are as follows As well as the Lua script can be found here Put the script in the same folder where you launch the test_encode command In this example Ambarella uses IMX274_MIPI with 4 K input resolution Pyramid input is main buffer which has a 4 K output resolution Then the pyramid Layer 1 is re-scaled from 4 K to 7 2 0 p Resource Configure Item Description Sensor IMX274_MIPI 3 8 4 0 x 2 1 6 0 Pyramid Input Main Buffer 3 8 4 0 x 2 1 6 0 Scale Type scale_type 2 Apply pyramid arbitraty scale and the downsampling ratio will be 2 Pyramid Rescale Size rescale_size 1 2 8 0 7 2 0 Pyramid Layer 1 will be re-scaled to 7 2 0 p Pyramid Layer Map layer_map 0 x7F Enable the pyramid from layer 0 to layer 6 In this case Layer 0 is copied from the input buffer The size of Layer 0 is the same as the output of the input buffer Then Layer 1 is re-scaled from 4 K to 7 2 0 p After that each layers will be down-sampled with the ratio of 2 This example shows the method on how to change the rescale size from 1 0 8 0 p to 7 2 0 p and the layer map from to dynamically In this example the initial pyramid configurations are set as shown in the following table when entering the preview state Preview Resource Configuration Item Description Sensor IMX274_MIPI 3 8 4 0 x 2 1 6 0 Pyramid Input Main Buffer 3 8 4 0 x 2 1 6 0 Scale Type scale_type 2 Apply pyramid arbitraty scale and downsampling ratio will be 2 Pyramid Rescale Size max_rescale_size 1 9 2 0 1 0 8 0 Pyramid Layer 1 size should no greater than 1 9 2 0 x1080 rescale_size 1 9 2 0 1 0 8 0 Pyramid Layer 1 will be re-scaled to 1 0 8 0 p Pyramid Layer Map max_layer_map 0 x3F Only layers within max layers map can be turned on/off dynamically layer_map 0 x1F Enable the pyramid from Layer 0 to Layer 4 After entering the preview state users can change the pyramid rescale size and the layer map dynamically As an example in following table the pyramid rescale size is updated to 7 2 0 p and the layer map is updated to Target Resource Configuration Item Description Pyramid Rescale Size rescale_size 1 2 8 0 7 2 0 Pyramid Layer 1 will be re-scaled to 7 2 0 p Pyramid Layer Map layer_map 0 x3F Enable the pyramid from Layer 0 to Layer 5 Here is an example for used external memory for pyramid As well as the Lua script can be found here
