BASIC HDR BASIC HDR Line-Interleaved high dynamic range HDR is also named as DOL HDR In this HDR mode sensor outputs multiple sub-exposure frames to CV5x VIN controller in line-interleaved format There are usually dummy lines between two adjacent sub-exposure frames Additionally the count of the dummy lines depends on the maximum exposure time of middle or short sub-exposure frame Lua script to configure the VIN canvas buffer layouts streams is as follows vin0_4k_dcg_hdr.lua.lua
b6_serdes_cal UINT32 ChipID AMBA_B6_SERDES_RATE_e SerDesRate UINT32 TimeInterval AMBA_B6_SERDES_PHY_CONFIG_s pCalibPhyConfig pMemBase

ADVANCED Pipeline Latency ADVANCED Pipeline Latency This chapter illustrates the IDSP latency of different video input VIN mode cases which are measured under the following two circumstances The table below records the latency between when VIN capture is completed and the IDSP YUV is output under different VIN modes It is measured with sensor input The latency here does not include the latency between the sensor beginning exposure and the frame being captured completed by VIN can be supported in only encode mode 0 VIN Capture Done to IDSP YUV Output Latency CV5s88 NO Encode Mode VIN 1 0 8 0 p60 VIN 4 kp30 VIN 4 Kp60 Latency ms Latency frames Latency ms Latency frames Latency ms Latency frames 1 0 10.48 0.63 19.56 0.59 19.81 1.19 The table below records the latency between feeding a raw image and the IDSP YUV output It is measured with encode from raw EFR Feed Raw Data to IDSP YUV Output Latency NO Encode Mode VIN ms Latency ms Latency frames 0 0 4 Kp30 15.6 0.46 To increase the latency reliability between VIN capture and VOUT display use a high refresh-rate LCD screen as an input The table below records the latency between VIN capture and VOUT display under different VIN modes VIN Capture to VOUT Display Latency NO Encode Mode 1 0 8 0 p60VIN-- 1 0 8 0 p60VOUT CV5S88 4 Kp60VIN-- 4 Kp60VOUT CV5S88 Latency ms Latency frames Latency ms Latency frames 1 0 6 2 3.72 7 7 4.62 The measurement method is shown as below It uses case as an example The PC monitor 1 0 8 0 p 1 4 4 Hz runs a timer on the left Its image will be captured and processed by the CV5S88 evaluation kit EVK and output to the right monitor through the high-definition multimedia interface HDMIÂ® VOUT If using another camera to take the photo of these two monitors the latency between VIN capture and VOUT display will be the time difference of the timers in these two monitors of the same photo Figure 1-1 Latency Between VIN Capture and VOUT Display Each test result is as shown below Encode Mode 0 1 0 8 0 P60 VIN 1 0 8 0 p60 VOUT Figure 1-2 Latency Between 1080p60VIN Capture and 1080p60VOUT Display enc-mode 0 Encode Mode 0 4 KP60 VIN 4 KP60 VOUT Figure 1-3 Latency Between 4KP60VIN Capture and 4KP60VOUT Display enc-mode 0 This chapter describes the usage of measuring encode latency Users can measure the encode latency via the following command after starting the stream As shown in the log below monotonic_pts represents the frame presentation time stamp PTS before encoding and enc_done_pts represents the frame PTS after encoding The difference between enc_done_pts and monotonic_pts is the frame encoding time which is recorded as enc_pipe_time in units of ticks As there are 9 0 0 0 0 ticks in one second users can convert the ticks to normal time with the equation Ticks 9 0 Millisecond For example if the enc_pipe_time is 4 5 0 0 the normal time should be 4 5 0 0 9 0 5 0 ms The latency mentioned here is measured from the time of VIN capture completion to completion of frame encoding It does not include the latency between the sensor beginning exposure and this frame being captured completed by VIN The table below records the latency between and âFrame encode doneâ It is measured with sensor input Encoding Latency CV5 NO Format Slice Num VDSP Mode VIN 4 Kp30 CV5S88 VIN 4 Kp60 CV5S88 Latency ms Latency frames Latency ms Latency frames 1 AVC 2 Single core 16.588 0.498 16.772 1.003 2 AVC 1 Dual core(temporal) 52.122 1.564 52.466 3.165 3 HEVC 2 Single core 16.561 0.497 16.783 1.007 4 HEVC 1 Dual core(temporal) 52.088 1.563 52.3 3.13 5 HEVC 1 Dual core(spatial) 15.755 0.473 15.955 0.957 Ambarella integrated the image audio video IAV audit tool into the Linux proc file to enable real-time monitoring of video pipeline information The audit tool currently supports the following DSP interrupt processing duration DSP interrupt interval IDSP latency encode latency IDSP frame drop encode frame drop vout frame drop frame sync(osd, overlay and blur) VIN-VOUT synchronization latency IDSP and encode clock Users can use the function in the shell to pass two arguments separated by a space The first parameter is the bitmap to enable auditing and the second parameter is the duration of the audit When the parameter is set successfully users can use to retrieve the audit results for the next few seconds determined by the second parameter in units The printout details the four main pieces of DSP interrupt audit information vdsp venc vcap and vin shows the processing and scheduling time of each interrupt on the ArmÂ® side and shows the interval time information of two adjacent interrupts for each interrupt type The printout details the average latency Avg maximum latency Max minimum latency Min and the difference between the maximum and minimum latency Delta over one second for each canvas Encode latency statistics are for streams that are in the encoding state Note that when obtaining encode latency statistics ensure that the system is in the encoding state otherwise there will be no valid statistics In the example the Delta in Encode Delay Info is very large The main reason for this phenomenon is that the I-frame in the stream processing time is long while the P-frame processing time is short so the difference between the two Delta is large shows the latency between VIN capture completed and VOUT display and can also help users to verify if the VIN-VOUT precise sync feature takes effect See VIN-VOUT Precise sync is used to audit the IDSP frame drop count and can help users obtain the actual IDSP frame per second fps when there is IDSP frame drop Status reflects the current IDSP state When Drop Count is greater than 0 it means that the current IDSP is in the frame-dropped state Frame dropped Otherwise it is in the normal OK state is used to audit the raw cuont being discard by IDSP proactively for the cases like the raw is not within the channel grouping tolerance If frame discard is reported in the audit info users can use âtest_encode debug-chan-group-toleranceâ to adjust the chan group sync tolerance value to adapt RAW capture done time drift between different sensors within one group is used to audit the encode advanced video coding AVC high-efficiency video coding HEVC MJPEG frame drop count Encode clock audit is used to audit the actual encode clock and compare whether the clock is configured correctly In order to make audit clock accurate it only supports run the specific use case of 4 K is for height alignment HEVC encode with on stream 0 The error shown by is reasonable within 1 is use to audit vout frame dorp and osd frame sync fail info When the vout fps is lower than the canvas fps vout will not be able to display all frames in time which will cause vout to drop frames and sync osd to frame fail is used to audit stream overlay and blur sync fail info At present ARM side can only audit the fail count of all streams from DSP and can t distinguish them for each stream Ambarella has opened the input output control IOCTL interface to implement video pipeline information auditing The show_video_audit_info application is available for users to easily obtain the same statistics info as the IAV audit proc

BASIC Frame Rate BASIC Frame Rate Each processing stage can have a different frame rate The variance in the frame rate can occur in any of the following components Figure 1 1 Frame Rate at Different Stages VIN fps Each sensor can be configured at different frame rate The video input VIN frames per second fps are used as the input frame rate for VIN stage inside digital signal processor DSP RAW fps At VIN stage it can output different frame rates for RAW data from VIN fps The RAW fps must be no larger than VIN fps which means that VIN can choose to skip sending RAW data to dynamic random access memory DRAM This can save DRAM bandwidth for RAW data Normally RAW fps is equal to VIN fps But it may be different for some scenarios such as scale or region of interest ROI VIN cases For scale or ROI VIN cases it may possibly generate multiple RAW data from the same sensor input frame Channel fps or IDSP fps For each processing channel the output frame rate image digital signal processing IDSP fps can vary from the input frame rate RAW fps This frame rate can be larger or smaller than the original RAW fps When it is larger than RAW fps IDSP periodically generates intermediated frames When the rate is smaller than RAW fps IDSP periodically skips RAW frames Canvas fps Each canvas can have a different frame rate The input fps for the canvas is its channel IDSP fps and the output fps is the canvas fps The output fps can be equal to or smaller than the channel IDSP fps IDSP periodically skips frames to generate smaller canvas fps out of the channel IDSP fps Pyramid fps If manual feeding is not used the pyramid fps should have the same frame rate as the channel IDSP fps If manual feeding is used the pyramid fps is dependent on Arm s feeding speed up to the channel IDSP fps Stream fps The stream fps is the actual encoding frame rate and its input frame rate is canvas fps The stream fps can be equal to or smaller than its input canvas frame rate Users can use the frame factor based on the canvas fps to specify the stream fps Video digital signal processor VDSP periodically skips frames to generate the smaller stream fps Users can also use stream-abs-fps-enable and stream-abs-fps option to enable a fixed smaller stream fps VOUT fps The video output VOUT fps is the actual VOUT display output frame rate and its input frame rate is canvas fps The VOUT fps can be larger or smaller than its input canvas fps When VOUT fps is smaller than its input canvas fps VOUT will periodically skips frames to meet the fps for the actual display device When VOUT fps is larger than its input canvas fps VOUT will display repeated frames periodically to meet the fps for the actual display device Table 1 1 Different fps Comparison fps type Stage Input fps fps Up-Sample fps Down-Sample Description VIN fps VIN input Sensor fps No No The same as sensor output fps RAW fps VIN output VIN fps No Yes No larger than VIN fps achieved by dropping frames periodically Channel fps IDSP input RAW fps Yes up to 3.99x Yes No limit for down-sample rate Canvas fps IDSP output Channel fps No Yes No limit for down-sample rate Pyramid fps IDSP output Channel fps No No fps down-sample possible with pyramid manual feed Stream fps VDSP input Canvas fps No Yes No limit for down-sample rate VOUT fps VOUT output Canvas fps Yes Yes Decided by the display configuration For frame rates across different stages more descriptions limitations are listed as followsï¼ Each VIN sensor can have a different fps Each RAW VIN output can have a different fps Each channel can have a different IDSP fps Each canvas can have a different fps When putting source buffers from different channels passes into the same canvas all these source buffers should have the same fps which should be equal to the final canvas fps The image audio video IAV module introduces the feature of high precision fps to express VIN IDSP and canvas framerate It is to support decimal fps like 0.5 or 7.5 By default this feature is disabled IAV can only support integral fps High precision fps is expressed by where hp_fps is high precision fps real_fps is real fps For example represents 0.5 fps represents 7.5 fps There are two methods to enable high precision frame rate IOCTL IAV_IOC_SET_SYSTEM_RESOURCE with member in struct iav_system_resource Lua scripts as below When this flag is enabled IAV will accept a frame rate value from structure high precision member with suffix not normal frame rate member The related structures show as below iav_pyramid_cfg frame_rate frame_rate_hp Related IOCTL IAV_IOC_SET_PYRAMID_CFG IAV_IOC_GET_PYRAMID_CFG iav_canvas_fps frame_rate frame_rate_hp Related IOCTL IAV_IOC_GET_VIDEO_PROC IAV_IOC_CFG_VIDEO_PROC iav_canvas_cfg frame_rate frame_rate_hp Related IOCTL IAV_IOC_GET_SYSTEM_RESOURCE IAV_IOC_SET_SYSTEM_RESOURCE iav_chan_cfg idsp_fps idsp_fps_hp Related IOCTL IAV_IOC_GET_SYSTEM_RESOURCE IAV_IOC_SET_SYSTEM_RESOURCE iav_stream_fps abs_fps abs_fps_hp Related IOCTL IAV_IOC_SET_STREAM_CONFIG IAV_IOC_GET_STREAM_CONFIG IAV will always report the frame rate to both high precision and normal frame rate member whether the flag is enabled or not For example when querying system resource through IAV_IOC_GET_SYSTEM_RESOURCE users can always get valid values in the structure iav_chan_cfg idsp_fps 3 0 idsp_fps_hp 3 0 0 0 0 This tool is used to query encode frame rate through the function and obtain the proper fps for the encoded stream for encoding The following example uses chip CV5S66 This feature allows the user to set non-integer VIN fps With option the IAV can set arbitrary fps For more details refer to vin0_4k_linear_hps.lua See Example 3 Update Canvas Framerate at Runtime for this feature When the VIN fps is changed the user wants to keep the stream fps stable With stream-abs-fps-enable and stream-abs-fps options stream fps can keep unchanged Change the VIN fps the stream fps is unchanged The IAV requests that the input fps cannot be smaller than stream abs fps If the encoding input fps is smaller than the target fps the real fps of the encoding stream will be the same as the input fps Modify the Lua file for RAW fps set VIN fps to 3 0 RAW fps and IDSP fps to 1 5 The Lua script can be found at raw_fps.lua Users can set different RAW fps for scale VIN and ROI VIN Modify the Lua file The Lua script can be found at cv72_scale_crop_vin_raw_fps.lua VIN framerate can be updated on the fly test_vin option is used to specify the new framerate and option is used to specify vsrc_id when there are multi VINs

OTHER Debug Option OTHER Debug Option ADVANCED Pipeline Latency This function is used to debug the anonymous MMB auto-recycling feature It can help simulate customers using an anonymous MMB in multiple-thread or multiple-process cases This chapter demonstrates options related to digital signal processor DSP performance These options can aid the device in achieving improved performance under specific conditions This feature improves CV5x DSP performance as a debug option it is used only for multiple-video input VIN multiple-channel scenarios and is not applicable for single-channel cases Extra DSP resources may be required to support this option The following are three items for channel configuration that must be the same across all channels Table 5 1 Channel Configurations Item Description rotate_cw Enable 9 0 degree clockwise rotation expo_num Specify the digital overlap high dynamic range DOL-HDR exposure frame number vcap_mode_flags Fixed Value 0 x00 advanced ISO mode This is the mode for lowest latency from VIN to video output VOUT Use the option debug-perf-opt-enable to enable optimal DSP performance mode The example below encodes 2 0 streams from four channels For details refer to cv5_four_chan_2xhdr_20stream_dsp_opt_perf_mode.lua This feature supports two high-efficiency video coding HEVC encode modes 0 default 1 good quality The default is 0 Use debug-hevc-enc-mode option to specify the HEVC encode mode AAA statistics can be displayed on stream in real-time on-screen display OSD of the per-frame shows AAA statistics of this frame including shutter and gain so the user can debug the image quality via this feature The picture below shows the AAA statistics overlay Figure 4 1 AAA Statistics Display on Stream Here is an example of how to use it

BASIC Blur on Streams BASIC Blur on Streams In some particular situation users may need to apply mosaic effect ROI areas on streams For example users may need to draw mosaic on human face to avoid the potential legal issue Or there are some privacy regions on the stream need to be protected It is supported to insert blur areas into streams Once blur areas are inserted the object will be so severely blurred that it cannot be recognized anymore There are two kinds of blur modes One is the normal blur which provides the standard rectangle blur area according to the provided size and coordinates The other is the arbitrary blur which allows users to customize their blur area shapes through changing specified blur area memory Users should allocate continuous memory allocator CMA memory part IAV_PART_BLUR for blur For arbitrary blur the user needs to allocate one more CMA memory part IAV_PART_ARB_BLUR Canvas Configuration Blur is inserted directly into the canvas blur_enable should be set for the canvas that will have a blur inserted Blur is inserted directly into the canvas Therefore streams encoding from the same canvas will see the same blur effect For example if both stream A and B encode from the canvas with the main buffer blur areas on stream A will also be shown on stream B and vice versa If both stream A and B insert blur the last blur configuration will take effect Blur is based on canvas coordinate system instead of stream coordinate system Blurred areas position does not vary with stream offset changing Figure 1-1 Blur is Based on Canvas Coordinate System Pyramid Configuration At least one pyramid layer should be enabled as pyramid is used to accomplish different blur strength Pyramid manual-feed mode won t save DRAM bandwidth when blur is enabled Blur strength decides the pyramid layer used as blur source Different blur areas in the same canvas must have the same strength To set different blurriness for different objects in the same canvas please use blur coefficients See Example 3 Apply Different Blur Coefficients on Stream Each canvas support up to 1 6 blur regions Total blur regions of all canvases cannot exceed 6 4 Too many blur regions will impact the image digital signal processing IDSP performance Hardware and Software Environment Please ensure that enough memory for blur is allocated See the following notes Whenever users need to use the blur feature it is required to allocate a memory partition in the CMA pool By default IAV_PART_BLUR partition size is 0 Users can allocate CMA memory part for blur via menuconfig For Cooper SDK Amba Build For Cooper SDK Yocto Build Alternatively users are able to change the CMA partition size on the fly Here are some example commands to enter preview and set up an AVC stream The Lua script can be found here Translucent Blur Mosaic can be applied to specified area(s) with specified color In order to apply color to the blur area users must initialize a color table for stream blur The length of the table is 1 6 Users can configure each entry in the color table with option In this test case the color table is shown as below Figure 2-1 Color Table Color of the blur area can be set with option In this example color of the blur area 0 is set to red Color of the blur area 1 is set to blue Figure 2-2 Blur on Stream Blocky Blur Specify blocky blur through option Figure 2-3 Blocky Blur on Stream Clear Blur Area Also all blurred areas can be cleared using the following command Hardware and Software Environment Both IAV_PART_BLUR and IAV_PART_ARB_BLUR memory part are needed to be allocated See the following notes Besides IAV_PART_BLUR memory partition users need to allocate another memory partition IAV_PART_ARB_BLUR for arbitrary blur Users can allocate CMA memory part for arbitrary blur via menuconfig For Cooper SDK Amba build For Cooper SDK Yocto build Alternatively users are able to change the CMA partition size on the fly Run arbitrary blur demo If it succeeds the random size diamond shape blur area will be set on stream A Figure 2-4 Arbitrary Blur on Stream Figure 2-5 Different Blur Coefficients on Stream Blur insertion can synchronize to a specific frame with PTS To support this feature canvas enc_dummy_latency option must be enabled first If the blur insertion fails to match with the specific PTS frame there will be error message reported from kernel dmesg log

ADVANCED Customized Features ADVANCED Customized Features This chapter illustrates the feature of capturing extra raw data which are usually embedded in the top or bottom lines of the sensor raw data The extra raw data is typically customized as sensor manufactured through mobile industry processor interface MIPIÂ® embedded lines When the user application performs Video content analysis VCA or 3 A AE AWB AF control the application may refer to the customized raw information which is embedded in the top or bottom lines of the sensor raw data The customized raw data is usually in a format specified by sensor manufacturer through MIPI embedded lines CV5x supports capturing this customized raw data from mobile industry processor interface MIPIÂ® embedded lines and attaching the data to corresponding canvas pyramid buffers or to 3 A statistic data For CV5x there is dedicated hardware support to capture the customized raw data Different from previous platforms CV5x is not required to to enforce uncompressed raw format to enable this feature This can save significant dynamic random access memory DRAM bandwidth for raw buffer transfer Users can specify compressed or packing raw data format when extra raw data is enabled Users can configure the extra raw data via the command line Below are the parameters for extra raw data capture Table 1 1 Extra Raw Data Item Parameter Description custom-extra-raw-vinc vinc id 0 Specify the target video input VIN controller ID custom-extra-raw-enable 0 disable 1 enable Enable disable the function of capture extra raw data function for specified VIN controllers custom-extra-raw-top 0 8 Specify the top lines of sensor raw data which will be captured as extra raw data custom-extra-raw-bottom 0 8 Specify the bottom lines of sensor raw data which will be captured as extra raw data For the âCapture Extra Raw Dataâ feature users are required to allocate a memory partition in the continuous memory allocator CMA pool By default the âIAV_PART_EXTRA_RAWâ partition size is 0 Users can allocate a CMA memory partition for âCapture Extra Raw Dataâ via memuconfig Users can calculate the total extra raw buffer size with the following fomula Extra raw buffer size pitch bottom lines top lines For Cooper SDK Amba build For Cooper SDK Yocto build The following example demonstrates how to enable the capture extra raw data function on CV5x platform and how to attach it to a canvas buffer

ADVANCED Encode Mode ADVANCED Encode Mode There are several encoding modes in the CV5x CV72 chips that provide different functionalities and performances for various products Although the CV5x CV72 platform currently has fewer encoding modes than CV2x platform additional modes are expected to be released in later versions For both the CV5x CV72 and CV2x chip series the field of the encoding mode must be explicitly specified The following table lists the differences in functions for encode mode comparison Table 1 1 Encode Mode Comparison Function Mode 0 Mode 1 Mode 5 Mode 1 2 7 IQ in low light Good Good Excellent No Single region LDC Yes No Yes No EIS Yes No Yes No Multi-Region dewarp No Yes No No HDR 2 X Yes Yes Yes No HDR 3 X No No Yes No Multi-VIN Yes No Yes No Multiple YUV input Yes Yes Yes No Single-Color privacy mask Yes Yes Yes No Multi-Color privacy mask No No No No For mode 0 the DSP pipeline latency is lower than mode 5 Compared with mode 0 mode 5 has better image quality with better MCTF effects for low light conditions Mode 0 and mode 1 has the same image quality For mode 1 2 7 it is VIN only mode and it is normally used for RAW data capture purpose Table 1 2 Normal ISO Mode Feature Description Sensor Type CFA YUV Input Main Buffer Size Width 8 1 9 2 Stream Number Up to 2 0 streams Feature Included All normal ISO features Encoding Overlay Electronic image stabilization EIS Single-Color privacy mask Digital PTZ type I and II Up to 3 layers SVC-T for H.264 and H.265 Capturing RAW YUV ME1 ME0 data High MPixel encoding width 1 9 2 0 Up to 4 K 2 X line interleaved HDR MB level encode tools for H.264 and H.265 Frame sync mechanism Lens distortion correction Multi-VIN design IDSP rotate flip Feature Not Included Fisheye dewarping Multi-Pass scalers Fusion for RGB and IR channel Fusion for RGB and thermal channel Table 1 3 Multi-Region Warp Feature Description Sensor Type CFA YUV Input Main Buffer Size Width 4 0 9 6 Stream Number Up to 2 0 streams Feature Included All advanced ISO features Encoding Overlay Single-Color privacy mask Up to 3 layers of SVC-T for H.264 and H.265 Captures RAW YUV ME1 ME0 data High megapixel encoding width 1 9 2 0 MB level encode tools for H.264 and H.265 Frame sync mechanism Fisheye dewarping Digital PTZ Type II when the sub buffer is dewarped Warp DPTZ for each region Extra sharpen after Dewarp Feature Not Included Electronic image Stabilization EIS 3 X line interleaved HDR Digital PTZ type I and II Lens Distortion Correction Fusion for RGB and IR channel Fusion for RGB and thermal channel Refer to ADVANCED Multi-Region Dewarp for more details and examples Table 1 4 Advanced HDR Feature Description Sensor Type CFA YUV Input Main Buffer Size Width 8 1 9 2 Stream Number Up to 1 6 streams Feature Included All advanced ISO features Encoding Overlay Electronic image stabilization Single-Color privacy mask Digital PTZ type I and II Up to 3 layers SVC-T for H.264 and H.265 Capturing RAW YUV ME1 ME0 data High MPixel encoding width 1 9 2 0 Up to 4 KP 3 X line interleaved HDR MB level Encode tools for H.264 and H.265 Frame sync mechanism Lens distortion correction Multi-VIN design IDSP rotate/flip Feature Not Included Fisheye dewarping Fusion for RGB and IR channel Fusion for RGB and thermal channel Table 1 5 VIN Only Mode Feature Description Sensor Type CFA YUV input Main Buffer Size Width 8 1 9 2 Feature Included Capturing RAW Features Not Included All normal ISO features Encoding Overlay EIS Single-color privacy mask DPTZ type I and II Stream rotation flip Up to three layers of SVC-T for H.264 and H.265 Capturing YUV ME1 ME0 data High MPixel encoding width 1 9 2 0 Up to 4 K 2 x line-interleaved HDR MB-level encode tools for H.264 and H.265 Frame sync mechanism Lens distortion correction 3 x HDR with any resolution Fisheye dewarping Multi-pass scalers IDSP rotate flip Multi-color privacy mask Fusion for RGB and IR channels Fusion for RGB and thermal channels This mode only captures data raw for use cases such as time of flight ToF Lidar and others
